testcase.name: com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testGetAllOrders

failure.message:
Misplaced or misused argument matcher detected here:
-> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testSaveProduct_Failure(Controller_AdminTest.java:226) -> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testUpdateProduct_Success(Controller_AdminTest.java:300) -> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testUpdateProduct_Success(Controller_AdminTest.java:300) -> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testSaveProduct_Success(Controller_AdminTest.java:195)
You cannot use argument matchers outside of verification or stubbing. Examples of correct usage of argument matchers: when(mock.get(anyInt())).thenReturn(null); doThrow(new RuntimeException()).when(mock).someVoidMethod(any()); verify(mock).someMethod(contains("foo"))
This message may appear after an NullPointerException if the last matcher is returning an object like any() but the stubbed method signature expect a primitive argument, in this case, use primitive alternatives. when(mock.get(any())); // bad use, will raise NPE when(mock.get(anyInt())); // correct usage use
Also, this error might show up because you use argument matchers with methods that cannot be mocked. Following methods *cannot* be stubbed/verified: final/private/equals()/hashCode(). Mocking methods declared on non-public parent classes is not supported.

testcase.failure:
org.mockito.exceptions.misusing.InvalidUseOfMatchersException: Misplaced or misused argument matcher detected here: -> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testSaveProduct_Failure(Controller_AdminTest.java:226) -> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testUpdateProduct_Success(Controller_AdminTest.java:300) -> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testUpdateProduct_Success(Controller_AdminTest.java:300) -> at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testSaveProduct_Success(Controller_AdminTest.java:195) You cannot use argument matchers outside of verification or stubbing. Examples of correct usage of argument matchers: when(mock.get(anyInt())).thenReturn(null); doThrow(new RuntimeException()).when(mock).someVoidMethod(any()); verify(mock).someMethod(contains("foo")) This message may appear after an NullPointerException if the last matcher is returning an object like any() but the stubbed method signature expect a primitive argument, in this case, use primitive alternatives. when(mock.get(any())); // bad use, will raise NPE when(mock.get(anyInt())); // correct usage use Also, this error might show up because you use argument matchers with methods that cannot be mocked. Following methods *cannot* be stubbed/verified: final/private/equals()/hashCode(). Mocking methods declared on non-public parent classes is not supported.
at com.revature.controller.Controller_AdminTest.testGetAllOrders(Controller_AdminTest.java:412)
